content.question: The base of a solid is the region in the first quadrant bounded by the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>- and <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axes and the graph of <math alttext="y equals, the fraction with numerator open parenthesis, x minus 2, close parenthesis, squared, and denominator 2 times, open parenthesis, x plus 1, close parenthesis " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. For the solid, each cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is a rectangle whose height is three times its width in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane. What is the volume of the solid?

topic.text: 8.7: Volumes with Cross Sections - Squares and Rectangles

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
